title: Analyzing browserify bundles to minimize JavaScript bundle size
When building web apps, it’s important to keep the size of JavaScript code delivered to the browser as small as possible.

inline_content.Text: When building web apps, it’s important to keep the size of JavaScript code delivered to the browser as small as possible.

title: I write in ES6 or TypeScript then use browserify to combine all JavaScript code into a single bundle file. For production builds I use uglify to make the bundle smaller.

inline_content.Text: I write in ES6 or TypeScript then use browserify to combine all JavaScript code into a single bundle file. For production builds I use uglify to make the bundle smaller.

title: Unfortunately, by default we are blind to what ends up in the final bundle. A single
import
c
can introduce surprising, unneeded dependencies.

inline_content.Text: Unfortunately, by default we are blind to what ends up in the final bundle. A single

title: First step of fixing bloat is to see what code ends up in the final bundle.

inline_content.Text: First step of fixing bloat is to see what code ends up in the final bundle.

title: Disc
a
http://hughsk.io/disc/
is one tool that visualizes the content of JavaScript bundle.

fullPaths: true
c
option to
browserify
c

a
https://www.npmjs.com/package/source-map-explorer

title: Disc and source-map-explorer can tell you what but not why.

inline_content.Text: Disc and source-map-explorer can tell you what but not why.

title: When you see a JavaScript package that shouldn’t be there, you need to know why it’s there i.e. where it was imported from.

inline_content.Text: When you see a JavaScript package that shouldn’t be there, you need to know why it’s there i.e. where it was imported from.

title: I haven’t found a tool that makes it easy, but it’s possible to create a primitive debug tool yourself.

inline_content.Text: I haven’t found a tool that makes it easy, but it’s possible to create a primitive debug tool yourself.

title: It’s not an ideal presentation but you can figure out who ultimately imports a given JavaScript file by chasing chain of imports.

inline_content.Text: It’s not an ideal presentation but you can figure out who ultimately imports a given JavaScript file by chasing chain of imports.

title: How does it help in practice? Here are 2 examples of how I reduced JavaScript bundle bloat by using those tools.

inline_content.Text: How does it help in practice? Here are 2 examples of how I reduced JavaScript bundle bloat by using those tools.

title: In
QuickNotes
a
https://github.com/kjk/quicknotes
I use
highlight.js
a
https://highlightjs.org/
library to do syntax highlighting for code snippets.

inline_content.Text: library to do syntax highlighting for code snippets.

title: Looking at output of source-map-explorer I noticed that highlight.js is 476 kB in size. That seemed excessive.

inline_content.Text: Looking at output of source-map-explorer I noticed that highlight.js is 476 kB in size. That seemed excessive.

title: The problem was that while core of highlight.js is small, it supports 168 languages and doing
import 'highlight.js'
c
would bundle all of.

inline_content.Text: The problem was that while core of highlight.js is small, it supports 168 languages and doing

title: I only need to support small subset of most popular languages.

inline_content.Text: I only need to support small subset of most popular languages.

title: One way to fix it would be to use https://highlightjs.org/download/ to generate a custom bundle. That would require repeating this manual step when I want to use the newer version.

inline_content.Text: One way to fix it would be to use https://highlightjs.org/download/ to generate a custom bundle. That would require repeating this manual step when I want to use the newer version.

title: I settled on a hacky but more automated solution.

inline_content.Text: I settled on a hacky but more automated solution.

title: I created a custom
index.js
c
that only imports the languages I want. Bbefore every compilation, I over-write
node_modules/highlight.js/index.js
c
with my custom version.

inline_content.Text: that only imports the languages I want. Bbefore every compilation, I over-write

title: That way I can still use npm to manage the library and easily update to new version.

inline_content.Text: That way I can still use npm to manage the library and easily update to new version.

title: When inspecting our JavaScript bundle I noticed suspicious libraries in it, like asn1 decoder.

inline_content.Text: When inspecting our JavaScript bundle I noticed suspicious libraries in it, like asn1 decoder.

title: I suspected our code doesn’t do asn1 decoding. Searching the codebase didn’t turn up any direct use.

inline_content.Text: I suspected our code doesn’t do asn1 decoding. Searching the codebase didn’t turn up any direct use.

title: I speculated that it’s imported indirectly by some other library.

inline_content.Text: I speculated that it’s imported indirectly by some other library.

title: I used my ad-hoc dependency tree dump to figure out that this code is imported from
seedrandom.js
c

inline_content.Text: I used my ad-hoc dependency tree dump to figure out that this code is imported from

title: This piece of code is a culprit:

inline_content.Text: This piece of code is a culprit:

title: Since node libraries are available during build step this line adds 294 kB of unneeded crypto code to our web app.

inline_content.Text: Since node libraries are available during build step this line adds 294 kB of unneeded crypto code to our web app.

title: The fix was to fork the repo and remove those lines.

inline_content.Text: The fix was to fork the repo and remove those lines.

title: It’s handy to be able to re-run this analysis. Here’s a sample script
analyze_bundle.sh
c
I have in one of my projects:

inline_content.Text: It’s handy to be able to re-run this analysis. Here’s a sample script
I have in one of my projects:

title:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -u -e -o pipefail

# uses source-map-explorer (https://www.npmjs.com/package/source-map-explorer)
# to visualize what modules end up in final javascript bundle.

install_sme() {
  if [ ! -f ./node_modules/.bin/source-map-explorer ]; then
    npm install source-map-explorer
  fi
}

analyze_prod()
{
  rm -rf s/dist/*
  install_sme

  ./node_modules/.bin/gulp jsprod
  ./node_modules/.bin/source-map-explorer s/dist/bundle.min.js s/dist/bundle.min.js.map
}

analyze_prod

content_resolved.code:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -u -e -o pipefail

# uses source-map-explorer (https://www.npmjs.com/package/source-map-explorer)
# to visualize what modules end up in final javascript bundle.

install_sme() {
  if [ ! -f ./node_modules/.bin/source-map-explorer ]; then
    npm install source-map-explorer
  fi
}

analyze_prod()
{
  rm -rf s/dist/*
  install_sme

  ./node_modules/.bin/gulp jsprod
  ./node_modules/.bin/source-map-explorer s/dist/bundle.min.js s/dist/bundle.min.js.map
}

analyze_prod
